text: Describe some patterns you have learned about multiples and factors of whole numbers.

Student responses may include many answers. This is a chance to pre-assess where students are in their understandings. There can be a range of answers.

  • Students might discuss patterns related to the ideas learned in previous grades, such as prime numbers and composite numbers.
  • Students might discuss patterns related to the one introduced by the student characters in the What If...?
  • Students may deepen ideas around the patterns discussed in the What If...?
  • Students may mention new patterns

Some patters might be from the generalizing statements about numbers. An example might include that to find all the whole- number factors of a number (N), you can divide the number by 1, 2, 3,... up to half of the number (1/2 N).

Some patterns might be from the Analysis of First Moves in the Factor Game chart. An example might be that some first moves give you and your opponent the same score. (These are perfect numbers.)

Students may answer in a variety of ways, which may include the following:

  • The first moves that have 3 as a factor are all multiples of 3.
  • Even numbers have 2 as a factor.
  • 1 is neither prime nor composite.
  • Square numbers have an odd number of factors.
